0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Ocular hypertension - Raised intraocular pressure: 1 drop TOPICALLY to affected eye(s) once daily in the evening; MAX use once daily
  • Open-angle glaucoma - Raised intraocular pressure: 1 drop TOPICALLY to affected eye(s) once daily in the evening; MAX use once daily

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Ocular hypertension - Raised intraocular pressure
  • Open-angle glaucoma - Raised intraocular pressure

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• intraocular inflammation, active, may be exacerbated
  • macular edema, including cystoid macular edema, has been reported with prostaglandin F2-alpha analogs; caution advised in aphakic patients, pseudophakic patients with a torn posterior lens capsule, or patients with known risk factors for macular edema
  • pigmentation of the iris, permanent, has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Neurologic:Headache (6%)
  • Ophthalmic:Conjunctival hyperemia (4% to 20%), Eye irritation (7%), Itching of eye (5%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tafluprost is a prostaglandin analog and a selective FP prostanoid receptor agonist. The exact mechanism of action of tafluprost is unknown, but it is believed to decrease intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: concentrations below the level of quantification 30 minutes following administration

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
General Information
  • provided in single-use containers, use immediately after opening, discard remainder
  • if more than 1 ophthalmic products is used, wait at least 5 minutes between administration of each product

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension: reduction in intraocular pressure is indicative of efficacy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that drug may cause increased pigmentation to iris, eyelid, and eyelashes.
  • Warn patient that drug may cause eyelash changes (eg, increased length, color, thickness, shape, and number of lashes).
  • Drug may cause conjunctival hyperemia.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of macular edema (eg, blurred vision, change in vision).
  • Counsel patient to only use drug once daily since more frequent dosing may decrease effectiveness.
  • Instruct patient to use solution immediately after container is opened and discard any remaining drug.
  • Advise patient using concomitant ophthalmic product to separate dosing of each product by 5 minutes.
